entry.et: Middle English, from Old English plantian, from Late Latin plantare to plant, fix in place, from Latin, to plant, from planta plant

def.dt: :to put or set in the ground for growth plant seeds
:to set or sow with seeds or plants
:implant
:establish institute
:colonize settle
:to place (animals) in a new locality
:to stock with animals
:to place in or on the ground
:to place firmly or forcibly planted a hard blow on his chin
:conceal
:to covertly place for discovery, publication, or dissemination
:to plant something

entry.et: Middle English plante, from Old English, from Latin planta

def.dt: :a young tree, vine, shrub, or herb planted or suitable for planting
:any of a kingdom (Plantae) of multicellular eukaryotic mostly photosynthetic organisms typically lacking locomotive movement or obvious nervous or sensory organs and possessing cellulose cell walls
:the land, buildings, machinery, apparatus, and fixtures employed in carrying on a trade or an industrial business
:a factory or workshop for the manufacture of a particular product
:power plant
:the total facilities available for production or service
:the buildings and other physical equipment of an institution
:an act of planting
:something or someone planted
:food 1b
:fertilizer
:an organic substance other than a nutrient that in minute amounts modifies a plant physiological process
:one produced by a plant and active elsewhere than at the site of production
:a basic group of natural objects that includes all living and extinct plants compare animal kingdom mineral kingdom
:aphid
:any of various small insects (as a jumping plant louse) of similar habits
city W cen Florida E of Tampa pop 29,915
:epiphyte
:any of several kalanchoes (especially Kalanchoe pinnata)
:a tropical Old World herb (Ricinus communis) widely grown as an ornamental or for its oil-rich castor beans
:a Mexican agave (Agave americana) that takes many years to mature, flowers only once, and then dies
